channel.title: BCEL: How Do I Get A Method Argument?

item.title: BCEL: How Do I Get A Method Argument?
item.dc:creator: @solarwind solarwind
item.description:
@solarwind wrote:

[quote=“frank_, post:20, topic:188662”]YEAH DAFAN, WAY TO POON YOUR BOYFRIEND nocaps nocaps nocaps nocaps

ps, i had code to do this exact thing inside a command line interface i was developing

wut you do is this…

get the list of local variables
if the method is not static
increment position by 1
for every argument at position n
get the name and type of the local variable position + n
if type is long or double
increment n by 2
else
increment n by 1

edit: da rs has local variable names removed[/quote]
Thanks! First helpful post you gave me!

Read full topic
item.source: BCEL: How Do I Get A Method Argument?

wut you do is this…

item.source: BCEL: How Do I Get A Method Argument?

item.title: BCEL: How Do I Get A Method Argument?
item.dc:creator: @Discount_Waffles Discount Waffles
item.description:
@Discount_Waffles wrote:

Method descriptors do not contain the original variable names of the method. There is no way to get the original names (in your case, vars a, b, and c). The only thing preserved is the order and types of the arguments.

So, in your example the method signature is (ILjava/lang/String;[Ljava/lang/String;)V but the only thing you can get out of that is the fact that there are 3 args, (int var1, String var2, String[] var3).

Hope that helps…The JVM spec has a pretty good definition -> http://java.sun.com/docs/books/jvms/second_edition/html/ClassFile.doc.html#14152

Read full topic
item.source: BCEL: How Do I Get A Method Argument?

item.title: BCEL: How Do I Get A Method Argument?
item.dc:creator: @BAsh_CntLgn BAsh(CntLgn)
item.description:
@BAsh_CntLgn wrote:

Run it through BCEL and set the local variable table to null/empty. Then dump it to disk. Run.

Read full topic
item.source: BCEL: How Do I Get A Method Argument?

item.title: BCEL: How Do I Get A Method Argument?
item.dc:creator: @solarwind solarwind
item.description:
@solarwind wrote:

BAsh(CntLgn):

Easy. You just need to define the signature of the method and the signature doesn’t allow names. Its up to the (optional) local variable table to define names intended for the debugger.

Example?

Read full topic

item.source: BCEL: How Do I Get A Method Argument?

item.title: BCEL: How Do I Get A Method Argument?
item.dc:creator: @solarwind solarwind
item.description:
@solarwind wrote:

[quote=“BAsh(CntLgn), post:6, topic:188662”]The bytecode viewer is showing you where those variables are stored. Not what their original names where.

Where you need to look is the local variable table but I think RS strips it. It might be added to ordinary scripts with the -g option but there again it might be by default.[/quote]
No, it’s there by default, trust me. How can you have a proper program without a local variable table anyway?

Read full topic
item.source: BCEL: How Do I Get A Method Argument?

item.title: BCEL: How Do I Get A Method Argument?
item.dc:creator: @BAsh_CntLgn BAsh(CntLgn)
item.description:
@BAsh_CntLgn wrote:

The bytecode viewer is showing you where those variables are stored. Not what their original names where.

Where you need to look is the local variable table but I think RS strips it. It might be added to ordinary scripts with the -g option but there again it might be by default.

Read full topic
item.source: BCEL: How Do I Get A Method Argument?

item.title: BCEL: How Do I Get A Method Argument?
item.dc:creator: @solarwind solarwind
item.description:
@solarwind wrote:

[quote=“unlimitedorb, post:4, topic:188662”][quote author=solarwind link=topic=251447.msg2105194#msg2105194 date=1205365792]
So what would happen if there were more than 3 arguments? Example:

public void test(int a, int b, int c, int d, int e, int f, int g, int h, int i)

How would they end in the table then?[br][br][size=1]Posted on: March 12, 2008, 02:56:12 PM[/size][hr]Nevermind, figured it out with bytecode viewer:

aload_0 iload_1 putfield DummyClass1/b I aload_0 iload_2 putfield DummyClass1/b I aload_0 iload_3 putfield DummyClass1/b I aload_0 aload 4 putfield DummyClass1/a Ljava/lang/String; aload_0 aload 5 putfield DummyClass1/a Ljava/lang/String; aload_0 aload 6 putfield DummyClass1/a Ljava/lang/String; return

One question though, why is it always calling aload_0 (loading this)?[br][br][size=1]Posted on: March 12, 2008, 02:57:07 PM[/size][hr]Why does it have to load this at all?
[/quote]

For the putfield… Putfield takes two arguments, the instance, and the value to put.[/quote]

Ohhh! Thanks!

Read full topic
item.source: BCEL: How Do I Get A Method Argument?

How would they end in the table then?[br][br][size=1]Posted on: March 12, 2008, 02:56:12 PM[/size][hr]Nevermind, figured it out with bytecode viewer:

aload_0 iload_1 putfield DummyClass1/b I aload_0 iload_2 putfield DummyClass1/b I aload_0 iload_3 putfield DummyClass1/b I aload_0 aload 4 putfield DummyClass1/a Ljava/lang/String; aload_0 aload 5 putfield DummyClass1/a Ljava/lang/String; aload_0 aload 6 putfield DummyClass1/a Ljava/lang/String; return

One question though, why is it always calling aload_0 (loading this)?[br][br][size=1]Posted on: March 12, 2008, 02:57:07 PM[/size][hr]Why does it have to load this at all?[/quote]

For the putfield… Putfield takes two arguments, the instance, and the value to put.

item.description:
@solarwind wrote:

So what would happen if there were more than 3 arguments? Example:

public void test(int a, int b, int c, int d, int e, int f, int g, int h, int i)

How would they end in the table then?[br][br][size=1]Posted on: March 12, 2008, 02:56:12 PM[/size][hr]Nevermind, figured it out with bytecode viewer:

aload_0 iload_1 putfield DummyClass1/b I aload_0 iload_2 putfield DummyClass1/b I aload_0 iload_3 putfield DummyClass1/b I aload_0 aload 4 putfield DummyClass1/a Ljava/lang/String; aload_0 aload 5 putfield DummyClass1/a Ljava/lang/String; aload_0 aload 6 putfield DummyClass1/a Ljava/lang/String; return

One question though, why is it always calling aload_0 (loading this)?[br][br][size=1]Posted on: March 12, 2008, 02:57:07 PM[/size][hr]Why does it have to load this at all?

item.title: BCEL: How Do I Get A Method Argument?
item.dc:creator: @unlimitedorb unlimitedorb
item.description:
@unlimitedorb wrote:

[quote=“solarwind, post:1, topic:188662”]How do I get the names and types of method arguments in BCEL? I can see that the method argument variables are in the local variable table.

For example, let’s say I have a method like this:

public void test(int a, String b, String[] c) {
//code here
}

How would I get the name and type of all the arguments? Example:
name: a type: int
name: b type: Ljava/lang/String
name: c type: [Ljava/lang/String

I need to access those arguments.[/quote]
Its not static, the arguments start at index 1 and end at 3 in the local variables. As 0 is a reference to the object’s instance (aka this :))

If it were static, it would be 0 to 2.

Read full topic
item.source: BCEL: How Do I Get A Method Argument?

item.title: BCEL: How Do I Get A Method Argument?
item.dc:creator: @solarwind solarwind
item.description:
@solarwind wrote:

How do I get the names and types of method arguments in BCEL? I can see that the method argument variables are in the local variable table.

For example, let’s say I have a method like this:

public void test(int a, String b, String[] c) {
//code here
}

How would I get the name and type of all the arguments? Example:
name: a type: int
name: b type: Ljava/lang/String
name: c type: [Ljava/lang/String

I need to access those arguments.

Read full topic
